natural problem:
Suppose $77\cdot 88\cdot 99 \equiv n\pmod{20}$, where $0\le n<20$.

What is the value of $n$?
natural solution: We begin by reducing the factors of the product modulo 20: \begin{align} 77 &\equiv -3\pmod{20},\\ 88 &\equiv 8\pmod{20},\\ 99 &\equiv -1\pmod{20}. \end{align}(Note that we could have used the more "standard" reductions $77\equiv 17$ and $99\equiv 19$, but the reductions above will make our computations easier.)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(77 * 88 * 99) mod 20 = n"
shows  "n = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose $77\cdot 88\cdot 99 \equiv n\pmod{20}$, where $0\le n<20$.

What is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 We begin by reducing the factors of the product modulo 20: \begin{align} 77 &\equiv -3\pmod{20},\\ 88 &\equiv 8\pmod{20},\\ 99 &\equiv -1\pmod{20}. \end{align}(Note that we could have used the more "standard" reductions $77\equiv 17$ and $99\equiv 19$, but the reductions above will make our computations easier.)
 Now we have \begin{align} 77\cdot 88\cdot 99 &\equiv (-3)\cdot 8\cdot(-1) \\ &= 24 \\ &\equiv \boxed{4}\pmod{20}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(77 * 88 * 99) mod 20 = n"
shows  "n = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the remainder when the product of 77, 88, and 99 is divided by 20? The final answer is 4.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(77 * 88 * 99) mod 20 = n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 20"
shows  "n = 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose $77\cdot 88\cdot 99 \equiv n\pmod{20}$, where $0\le n<20$.

What is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 We begin by reducing the factors of the product modulo 20: \begin{align} 77 &\equiv -3\pmod{20},\\ 88 &\equiv 8\pmod{20},\\ 99 &\equiv -1\pmod{20}. \end{align}(Note that we could have used the more "standard" reductions $77\equiv 17$ and $99\equiv 19$, but the reductions above will make our computations easier.)
 Now we have \begin{align} 77\cdot 88\cdot 99 &\equiv (-3)\cdot 8\cdot(-1) \\ &= 24 \\ &\equiv \boxed{4}\pmod{20}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(77 * 88 * 99) mod 20 = n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 20"
shows  "n = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the remainder when the product of 77, 88, and 99 is divided by 20. The answer should be a non-negative integer less than 20. The final answer is 4.
